H0.text: Metalloids are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

H1.text: Halogens are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

H2.text: Synthetics are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

H3.text: Noble gases are the third class of elements after metals and nonmetals.

A4.text: No widely accepted definition of a metalloid exists, nor any division of the periodic table into metals, metalloids, and nonmetals; Hawkes questioned the feasibility of establishing a specific definition

A5.text: Classifying an element as a metalloid has been described by Sharp as 'arbitrary'

A6.text: there is neither an IUPAC definition nor a precise consensus on exactly which elements should be considered metals, nonmetals, or semi-metals (sometimes called metalloids)

A8.text: Six nonmetals are classified as noble gases: helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon, and the radioactive radon.

A9.text: Some consider metalloids distinct from both metals and nonmetals, while others classify them as nonmetals.
